question.title: Is there a way to get a reference address?

node.contents: Either go back to the dark side of "C" where memory addresses plague your every thought, or come over to the light side, where memory addresses are neither needed nor wanted. Choose your path!

astNode.text: Either go back to the dark side of "C" where memory addresses plague your every thought, or come over to the light side, where memory addresses are neither needed nor wanted. Choose your path!

node.contents: You really shouldn't want to do it, which is what most of the people below are saying. Peter Lawry shows that you can do it (he beat me to mentioning it). Others are "wrong" in that sense. However, there is a reason the class is called "Unsafe". Another reason, is that this is a Sun/Oracle class and does not have to be implemented by other JVM implementors, so you can't rely on it in your code if you don't know where you are running.

astNode.text: You really shouldn't want to do it, which is what most of the people below are saying. Peter Lawry shows that you can do it (he beat me to mentioning it). Others are "wrong" in that sense. However, there is a reason the class is called "Unsafe". Another reason, is that this is a Sun/Oracle class and does not have to be implemented by other JVM implementors, so you can't rely on it in your code if you don't know where you are running.

node.contents: A rare circumstance for using this: instrumenting an activex / ocx control from java where the activex control requires a `long` pointer to a byte array as a parameter to one of it's methods. In other words, if you need to "bridge" between java and another language such as C++ this might be useful (if there are absolutely no other options).

astNode.text: A rare circumstance for using this: instrumenting an activex / ocx control from java where the activex control requires a `long` pointer to a byte array as a parameter to one of it's methods. In other words, if you need to "bridge" between java and another language such as C++ this might be useful (if there are absolutely no other options).

node.contents: The link I posted in my comment to Peter Lawry shows how you can do it, such that you can retain correct addresses (cause if you create objects using memory allocation, you can probably technically get outside the heap, where GC won't affect you). I'm guessing that is how Terracotta's BigMemory works.

astNode.text: The link I posted in my comment to Peter Lawry shows how you can do it, such that you can retain correct addresses (cause if you create objects using memory allocation, you can probably technically get outside the heap, where GC won't affect you). I'm guessing that is how Terracotta's BigMemory works.

node.contents: Actually address can be obtained with sun.misc.Unsafe but it is really very unsafe. GC often moves objects.

astNode.text: Actually address can be obtained with sun.misc.Unsafe but it is really very unsafe. GC often moves objects.

node.contents: What are the packages of these classes?

astNode.text: What are the packages of these classes?

node.contents: Yes, You can do it with Unsafe, Althrough it's not so directly. Put the object or instance reference into a int[], that's ok. long[] should be fine as well.

astNode.text: Yes, You can do it with Unsafe, Althrough it's not so directly. Put the object or instance reference into a int[], that's ok. long[] should be fine as well.

elements.contents:
@Test public void test1() throws Exception { Unsafe unsafe = Util.unsafe; int base = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(int[].class); int scale = unsafe.arrayIndexScale(int[].class); int shift = 31 - Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(scale); System.out.printf("base: %s, scale %s, shift: %s
", base, scale, shift); base = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(Object[].class); scale = unsafe.arrayIndexScale(Object[].class); shift = 31 - Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(scale); System.out.printf("base: %s, scale %s, shift: %s
", base, scale, shift); int[] ints = { 1, 2, 0 }; String string = "abc"; System.out.printf("string: id: %X, hash: %s
", System.identityHashCode(string), string.hashCode()); unsafe.putObject(ints, offset(2, shift, base), string); System.out.printf("ints: %s, %X
", Arrays.toString(ints), ints[2]); Object o = unsafe.getObject(ints, offset(2, shift, base)); System.out.printf("ints: %s
", o); assertSame(string, o); Object[] oa = { 1, 2, string }; o = unsafe.getObject(oa, offset(2, shift, base)); assertSame(string, o); int id = unsafe.getInt(oa, offset(2, shift, base)); System.out.printf("id=%X
", id); } public static long offset(int index, int shift, int base) { return ((long) index << shift) + base; }

", base, scale, shift); base = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(Object[].class); scale = unsafe.arrayIndexScale(Object[].class); shift = 31- Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(scale); System.out.printf("base: %s, scale %s, shift: %s
", base, scale, shift); int[] ints = { 1, 2, 0}; String string = "abc"; System.out.printf("string: id: %X, hash: %s
", System.identityHashCode(string), string.hashCode()); unsafe.putObject(ints, offset(2, shift, base), string); System.out.printf("ints: %s, %X
", Arrays.toString(ints), ints[2]); Object o = unsafe.getObject(ints, offset(2, shift, base)); System.out.printf("ints: %s
", o); assertSame(string, o); Object[] oa = { 1, 2, string }; o = unsafe.getObject(oa, offset(2, shift, base)); assertSame(string, o); int id = unsafe.getInt(oa, offset(2, shift, base)); System.out.printf("id=%X
", id); } public static long offset(int index, int shift, int base) { return ((long) index << shift) + base; }

node.contents: Just want to make sure some reference are the same.

astNode.text: Just want to make sure some reference are the same.

node.contents: If you want to compare two references, you can do that with ==. There's no need for you to get the object's address.

astNode.text: If you want to compare two references, you can do that with ==. There's no need for you to get the object's address.

node.contents: No, you cannot. Even using the Java Native Interface (JNI), you can only get an opaque handle to the data structure, not a pointer to the real JVM object.

astNode.text: No, you cannot. Even using the Java Native Interface (JNI), you can only get an opaque handle to the data structure, not a pointer to the real JVM object.

node.contents: Why would you want such a thing? It wouldn't necessarily be in a form you could use for anything, anyway, even from native code.

astNode.text: Why would you want such a thing? It wouldn't necessarily be in a form you could use for anything, anyway, even from native code.

node.contents: It's not possible in Java to get a reference address of an object, like your String. The reference address of an object is hidden to the user, in Java.

astNode.text: It's not possible in Java to get a reference address of an object, like your String. The reference address of an object is hidden to the user, in Java.

node.contents: In C, you can do this, through the concept of pointers. Java has a similar concept, at low-level,and this is the reference address. The reference is like a C pointer, but it's not explicit. In C, you can do the operation of referencing of pointers, through the *, but in Java, it's not possible.

astNode.text: In C, you can do this, through the concept of pointers. Java has a similar concept, at low-level,and this is the reference address. The reference is like a C pointer, but it's not explicit. In C, you can do the operation of referencing of pointers, through the *, but in Java, it's not possible.

node.contents: I don't like very much the C language, also because the pointers, according to me, are not an easy concept to manage. This is one of the reasons I like Java, because the programmer doesn't need to worry about the pointer of an object.

astNode.text: I don't like very much the C language, also because the pointers, according to me, are not an easy concept to manage. This is one of the reasons I like Java, because the programmer doesn't need to worry about the pointer of an object.

node.contents: Like @jarnbjo says, you can check, if some references are similar, with a syntax like this:

astNode.text: Like @jarnbjo says, you can check, if some references are similar, with a syntax like this:

elements.contents: String s = "hello"; String g = s; System.out.println("Are the reference addresses similar? "+(s==g)); g = "goodbye"; System.out.println("Are the reference addresses similar? "+(s==g));

units.rawText: String s = "hello"; String g = s; Systemoutprintln("Are the reference addresses similar? "+(s==g)); g = "goodbye"; Systemoutprintln("Are the reference addresses similar? "+(s==g));

node.contents: Note that == checks the equality of reference address. If you want to check the equality of the value of the strings, use the equals() method.

astNode.text: Note that == checks the equality of reference address. If you want to check the equality of the value of the strings, use the equals() method.

node.contents: This is neat stuff, but readers should take care to realize that this is not portable; the `Unsafe` class is an undocumented implementation detail of Sun-derived JVMs. This code won't work on J9, JRockit, Dalvik, etc.

astNode.text: This is neat stuff, but readers should take care to realize that this is not portable; the `Unsafe` class is an undocumented implementation detail of Sun-derived JVMs. This code won't work on J9, JRockit, Dalvik, etc.

node.contents: @PeterLawrey Is there any detailed explanation about the 32-bit and 64-bit thing? I am pretty interested in that.

node.contents: @dawnstar Here is a good link on that https://wikis.oracle.com/display/HotSpotInternals/CompressedOops

astNode.text: @dawnstar Here is a good link on that https://wikis.oracle.com/display/HotSpotInternals/CompressedOops

node.contents: You can get the object index with Unsafe. Depending on how the JVM is using the memory (32-bit addresses, 32-bit index, 32-bit index with offset, 64-bit address) can affect how useful the object index is.

astNode.text: You can get the object index with Unsafe. Depending on how the JVM is using the memory (32-bit addresses, 32-bit index, 32-bit index with offset, 64-bit address) can affect how useful the object index is.

node.contents: Here is a program which assumes you have 32-bit index in a 64-bit JVM.

astNode.text: Here is a program which assumes you have 32-bit index in a 64-bit JVM.

elements.contents: import sun.misc.Unsafe; import java.lang.reflect.Field; import java.util.Arrays; import java.util.Collections; public class OrderOfObjectsAfterGCMain { static final Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); static final boolean is64bit = true; // auto detect if possible. public static void main(String... args) { Double[] ascending = new Double[16]; for(int i=0;i<ascending.length;i++) ascending[i] = (double) i; Double[] descending = new Double[16]; for(int i=descending.length-1; i>=0; i--) descending[i] = (double) i; Double[] shuffled = new Double[16]; for(int i=0;i<shuffled.length;i++) shuffled[i] = (double) i; Collections.shuffle(Arrays.asList(shuffled)); System.out.println("Before GC"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); System.gc(); System.out.println("\nAfter GC"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); System.gc(); System.out.println("\nAfter GC 2"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); } public static void printAddresses(String label, Object... objects) { System.out.print(label + ": 0x"); long last = 0; int offset = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(objects.getClass()); int scale = unsafe.arrayIndexScale(objects.getClass()); switch (scale) { case 4: long factor = is64bit ? 8 : 1; final long i1 = (unsafe.getInt(objects, offset) & 0xFFFFFFFFL) * factor; System.out.print(Long.toHexString(i1)); last = i1; for (int i = 1; i < objects.length; i++) { final long i2 = (unsafe.getInt(objects, offset + i * 4) & 0xFFFFFFFFL) * factor; if (i2 > last) System.out.print(", +" + Long.toHexString(i2 - last)); else System.out.print(", -" + Long.toHexString( last - i2)); last = i2; } break; case 8: throw new AssertionError("Not supported"); } System.out.println(); } private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field theUnsafe = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafe.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) theUnsafe.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } } }

comments.text: // auto detect if possible. public static void main(String... args) { Double[] ascending = new Double[16]; for(int i=0;i<ascending.length;i++) ascending[i] = (double) i; Double[] descending = new Double[16]; for(int i=descending.length-1; i>=0; i--) descending[i] = (double) i; Double[] shuffled = new Double[16]; for(int i=0;i<shuffled.length;i++) shuffled[i] = (double) i; Collections.shuffle(Arrays.asList(shuffled)); System.out.println("Before GC"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); System.gc(); System.out.println("\nAfter GC"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); System.gc(); System.out.println("\nAfter GC 2"); printAddresses("ascending", ascending); printAddresses("descending", descending); printAddresses("shuffled", shuffled); } public static void printAddresses(String label, Object... objects) { System.out.print(label + ": 0x"); long last = 0; int offset = unsafe.arrayBaseOffset(objects.getClass()); int scale = unsafe.arrayIndexScale(objects.getClass()); switch (scale) { case 4: long factor = is64bit ? 8 : 1; final long i1 = (unsafe.getInt(objects, offset) & 0xFFFFFFFFL) * factor; System.out.print(Long.toHexString(i1)); last = i1; for (int i = 1; i < objects.length; i++) { final long i2 = (unsafe.getInt(objects, offset + i * 4) & 0xFFFFFFFFL) * factor; if (i2 > last) System.out.print(", +" + Long.toHexString(i2 - last)); else System.out.print(", -" + Long.toHexString( last - i2)); last = i2; } break; case 8: throw new AssertionError("Not supported"); } System.out.println(); } private static Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field theUnsafe = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); theUnsafe.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) theUnsafe.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new AssertionError(e); } } }

node.contents: Running on Java 6 update 26 (64-bit with compressed oops) and Java 7. Note: addresses and relative addresses are in hex.

node.contents: No, you cannot. Especially not as Java can (and AFAIK does) move objects around in the heap if it is needed for memory compacting during garbage collection.

astNode.text: No, you cannot. Especially not as Java can (and AFAIK does) move objects around in the heap if it is needed for memory compacting during garbage collection.
